title: Living and thriving with T1D
content: Jake Kushner, pediatric endocrinologist specializing in helping people with type 1 diabetes and Medical Director of McNair Interests, discusses the best strategies to live and thrive with T1D, especially as it relates to diet and exercise.

title: High amounts of exogenous insulin and risk
content: We also discuss why many patients who control their blood sugar with high amounts of exogenous insulin are at a substantially higher risk than people who can control their blood sugar at lower levels of insulin. This concept has great implications for non-diabetics as well considering the increasing prevalence of diseases related to insulin resistance.

title: Living with Type 1 Diabetes
content: Jake Kushner, pediatric endocrinologist specializing in helping people with type 1 diabetes, discusses the best strategies to live and thrive with T1D, especially as it relates to diet and exercise. We also discuss why many patients who control their blood sugar with high amounts of exogenous insulin are at a substantially higher risk than people who can control their blood sugar at lower levels.

title: The Pathophysiology of Type 1 Diabetes and Its Increasing Prevalence
content: Jake Kushner, pediatric endocrinologist, discusses the pathophysiology of type 1 diabetes, the increase in prevalence, and the role of beta cells. We also cover the role of body weight and BMI in the risk of developing T1D, genetics of T1D and the risk of inheritance, and Hemoglobin A1c.

title: The Complications Associated with Diabetes and High Blood Glucose Levels
content: We discuss the Diabetes Control and Complication Trial, cognitive impairment, epigenetic changes, and other dangers associated with high, peak blood glucose, and big swings in blood glucose levels. We also cover depression, anxiety, and other challenges of living with T1D.

title: Managing Diabetes with Exercise and Other Tools for Controlling T1D
content: Jake Kushner discusses managing diabetes with exercise, the Bernstein method, and protein’s impact on glucose and insulin. We also cover other tools for controlling T1D and whether the ketogenic diet is appropriate for those with T1D.

title: Lessons for the Non-Diabetic Population
content: We discuss the most important lessons that can be applied by the non-diabetic population, as well as the two dream measurements Peter wishes were available.

title: Type 1 Diabetes and DKA
content: About 30% of the kids that are diagnosed with type 1 diabetes present with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) which implies that they’ve had the illness for quite some time. When they present with diabetic ketoacidosis, it means that they have somehow managed to slip through the cracks. Nobody’s figured out that their glucose level is through the roof, or that they’re becoming acidotic or do these other things. And what actually brings them into the hospital is a septic-like situation. The presentation of DKA is less frequent in older people, who generally become diabetic at a slower pace which is known as cryptic type 1 diabetes. In these people… they probably have autoimmune antibodies, and they have some degree of loss of beta cells.

title: Type 1 Diabetes in Adults
content: The presentation of DKA is less frequent in older people, who generally become diabetic at a slower pace which is known as cryptic type 1 diabetes. In these people… they probably have autoimmune antibodies, and they have some degree of loss of beta cells ⇒ “and this phenomenon explains some of the adult onset diabetes that you just don’t quite understand”.

title: Type 1 Diabetes Overview
content: Type 1 is approximately one in 300 people. The typical age of onset is around nine years old. And they live into adulthood, and many can survive into their 80s. “It’s the most common life threatening, medication requiring, illness of childhood.”

title: Type 1 Diabetes
content: Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune condition largely driven by T cells, but there is also a contribution of B cells. By some combination of bad luck, genetics and possibly the foods you eat (to a very modest degree) this stochastic phenomenon begins to move forward whereby the beta cell, which secretes insulin, begins to dump off antigens. And the antigens begin to provoke the immune system locally and some of those immune cells start to destroy beta cells and dump out more antigens. When they begin to dump off their antigens and provoke autoimmunity, you can get this sort of death spiral. Where ultimately, the end result is a progressive autoimmunity, where you lose beta cells over time. In populations, the heavier you are, the more likely you are to have T1D (note: this doesn’t seem to hold up in individuals).

title: Diagnosing T1D
content: Greater awareness than in the past can catch T1D as early as 6 months, however, they don’t have classical signs and symptoms. If nobody bothers to check the serum glucose, you might never know that they in fact have life threatening diabetic ketoacidosis and new onset type 1 diabetes. It’s a disaster. Kids have a more aggressive onset. The condition becomes life threatening quicker and their autoimmunity is more aggressive because they don’t have the reserve of beta cells. Adults have a greater reserve of beta cells so their onset takes longer and is slowly progressing. This makes it difficult for a precise diagnosis. People are getting diagnosed at type 2, when instead they have cryptic type 1. This leads to incorrect treatment.

title: B Cells and T1D
content: The beta cells make very unique things, and when you break them open and destroy them, you begin to dump them out. There is both the B and a T cell response. We can test for antibodies in the serum of people with type 1 diabetes, and they make unique antibodies against insulin and GAD, glutamic acid decarboxylase, as well as a protein, tyrosine phosphatase called ICA 512. And so those antibodies are commonly used in the diagnosis of type 1 diabetes, which we believe to be a T cell disease. But that doesn’t make complete sense because antibodies are made by B cells, so there must be some contribution.

title: Proof of the role of B cells in T1D: Rituximab, B-Lymphocyte Depletion, and Preservation of Beta-Cell Function
content: A huge clinical trial using Rituximab, which alters B cell function, alters the ability of the B cells to make antibodies. They were able to delay the course of type 1 diabetes. Other autoimmune diseases that share this phenomenon where you have this B cell, T cell component: Autoimmune thyroid disease, where you can get thyroid peroxidase and thyroglobulin antibodies. Adrenal disease. Sialadenitis (rarely) which is autoimmune disease of the salivary gland. Oophoritis of the ovaries (also rare). Pernicious anemia, the ability to produce B12. Celiac disease.

title: The role of body weight and BMI in the risk of developing T1D
content: There’s no one precise thing. But there is some evidence that a higher BMI could predispose kids to T1D. Paper that has some evidence for the SAD being linked to T1D in kids: Excess BMI in Childhood: A Modifiable Risk Factor for Type 1 Diabetes Development?

title: Genetics of T1D and the risk of inheritance
content: There are certain HLA alleles that are quite common in the human population. Example, HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR4, and others. And when certain HLA are combined it increases the odds of having a child with T1D. The people who have T1D often have these alleles, and also these other minor alleles that by themselves contribute a small amount of risk, but in aggregate it increases quite a bit. Statistically, it adds up to a 10x increase that your child will have T1D if you have it. However, since T1D is 1 in 300 for the general population, a 10x increase only brings it to 1 in 30. Or said another way, there’s still a 97% chance your child will NOT inherit T1D.

title: Hemoglobin A1c
content: It’s a way to understand the average blood glucose a person has. It measures the amount of glycosylation, or how much glucose is sticking to hemoglobin. If we take the assumption that hemoglobin has a relatively finite, fixed, predictable life before the red blood cells themselves get broken down, we can measure the hemoglobin A1c and then impute the average blood glucose. Today, a diagnosis of T2D is made solely on the hemoglobin A1c being greater than 6.5%. It no longer relies on the insulin or glucose level during an oral glucose challenge.

title: Insulin: the amazing story of its discovery, its effect on cellular metabolism and IGF-1, and why the hell it’s so expensive
content: The story about the discovery of insulin: Banting and Best discovered insulin in 1921: Banting and Best: The Extraordinary Discovery of Insulin. Book recommendation: The Discovery of Insulin by Michael Bliss.

title: Discovery of Insulin
content: Prior to the discovery of insulin in 1921, patients who presented with symptoms of diabetes would die within days, weeks or months from diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). Banting and Best discovered insulin by blocking the outflow of the exocrine pancreas, which makes these digestive enzymes, force the pancreas it eat itself alive, and then taking this residual muck that comes from the pancreas and purifying whatever is within it to see if that is some sort of medicine that might be useful for type one diabetes.

title: Insulin and Metabolism
content: Insulin is a key factor in regulating virtually every cell in the body. It recognizes whether a cell is in a state of feast or famine. Insulin is a master regulator of your state of metabolism. In a muscle cell, it promotes glucose uptake into skeletal muscle. In a state of starvation, muscle is broken down and used for gluconeogenesis, creating a profound negative nitrogen balance. Insulin and IGF-1 one really are intensely overlapping in the way they work.

title: Discovery of Insulin
content: Banting recruits a medical student to help, Charles Best. Amazingly they are able to isolate this substance that has the ability to lower blood glucose in dogs. They then take it and put it back into a dog that they’ve removed the entire pancreas of, and it lowers the blood glucose in the dog. Shortly thereafter, they give insulin to a medical student with T1D and are able to lower his blood glucose. Banting and Macleod were awarded the Nobel Prize in 1923.

title: Recombinant Insulin
content: Insulin for human treatment originally came from pigs. A company called Genentech produced the first recombinant insulin. It used to be so cheap, about $25 for 1,000 units (a month’s supply). Now 1,000 units costs $300-$400. It’s really a disaster for people who are on the margins of society but want modern care and are willing to pay for it, but they can’t get insulin at the same price that, for instance, you could if you walked into a pharmacy in Spain.

title: Complications of Diabetes
content: Blindness is from abnormal vessel growth. In the kidneys, very high glucose can alter the epithelia of the kidney that’s involved in filtering blood and making urine. Amputations are due to altered healing. Together, these issues can be very bad diabetic wounds that fail to get better with antibiotic and ultimately result in amputation. This is the most common cause of preventable amputation in the United States. It’s also the most common cause of preventable blindness in the United States, and probably also renal failure. The DCCT set out to test whether tight control of blood glucose (i.e. near normal ranges) confers protection against diabetes complications. They found the answer to be yes, and they published their results in 1993. In other words, as the average blood glucose increases, the microvascular complications increase as well.

title: Controlling Blood Sugar in T1D
content: The challenge of controlling blood sugar in people with T1D is due to the volatility in blood glucose. Stress, sleep quality, exercise, and other things in food like fat and protein, also alter gastric emptying and the end result is a tremendous amount of variance in the system. There is no exact formula of insulin to carb ratio.

title: Details of, and the Controversy around, the DCCT
content: The DCCT trial was difficult to do because there were no established best practices to achieve near or normal blood glucoses at the time. Some well-meaning physicians thought it was foolish and dangerous to test this theory. The trial was supposed to run for 10 years but was stopped 7 years because the treatment group was seeing so much benefit from the intervention that it was no longer ethical to deprive the general population of this treatment.

title: Side Effects of Tight Control of Blood Glucose
content: Hypoglycemic events and weight gain are the side effects of tight control of blood glucose. The weight gain in type 1 diabetes is a serious problem and the people who have gained the most weight have had poor cardiovascular outcomes. It was argued by many that the only way towards tight control would be weight gain.

title: 30 Year Follow Up to the DCCT
content: Following the 7-year DCCT trial, the cohorts were merged and followed for another 23 years. The group that received tight control for 7 years had less cardiovascular disease and death than the group that received “conventional” treatment. In other words, the 7 years of tight control still retained some benefit from the seven years, 30 years earlier.

title: Dangers of exposure to high blood glucose and/or variability
content: Peter’s reading of the literature suggests that people, especially developing children, could have cognitive impairment associated with high blood glucose variability. Jake says it could be the variability or it could the exposure to high peak levels of blood glucose could actually cause epigenetic changes. Now there’s a whole rich field that’s devoted to this idea of these windows of hyperglycemia permanently altering these important cells that ultimately contribute to diabetes complications. Very short exposures to high blood sugars can completely change gene expression in a whole bunch of genes, like endothelial cells. So there’s a school of thought that says that diabetes complications are really around the exposures to these weird toxic levels of blood glucose that can occur.

title: Depression, anxiety and other challenges of living with T1D
content: There is no perfect formula to manage it that is also practical and easy for a patient. Challenges of managing blood glucose. Jake said many doctors still struggle with this. The ultimate bio hack. Jake tells a story of a friend of his who lives with T1D. But ultimately, she is finding a way to live her life while keeping her blood glucose “near normal”. Parenting a child with T1D. Cognitive Load of living with diabetes. This leads to anxiety and depression for many of those with T1D ⇒ About 40-50% of people with T1D. Quantifying the cognitive load with the “diabetes distress scale”.

title: Diabetes Burden
content: The patient answers on a 1 to 10 scale, with an average score of a teenager on a high-carb diet being 7 or 8. Jake says that people with diabetes, especially teens, are rarely ever asked how they feel. The medical establishment reinforces the endless cycle of blame and shame and negativity. When Jake can connect with a patient and manage to get their A1C from 14 down to 7, for example, it changes their life.

title: Continuous Glucose Monitor
content: In 2007, Jake is introduced to the original model of the continuous glucose monitor (CGM) made by Dexcom. However, it turns out that this first device was frustrating for patients because they didn’t really know what do with the information. Doctors would tell patients, “Oh, you need to check your blood glucose 20 minutes before the meal and give yourself insulin 20 minutes before the meal and do that in a very reliable way so that your blood glucose is normal.”

title: Managing Diabetes with Exercise
content: People can use exercise to help control their diabetes. Part of the mechanism is via the insulin-independent glucose uptake into skeletal muscle via AMP kinase. AMP kinase is an enzyme that is sensing the energy status of the cell. If you alter the energy status of the cell through a tremendous amount of work (exercise), it signals the GLUT4 to translocate to the membrane of the skeletal muscle. So now you get insulin-independent glucose uptake into skeletal muscle.

title: The Impact of Exercise on Insulin Sensitivity
content:
Is it that you are more sensitive to insulin itself (i.e. 1 unit of insulin invokes more GLUT4 translocation in someone who is exercising vs when they are not exercising) OR…
Is it more about AMPK and its effect on GLUT4 translocation?

title: The Bernstein Method and Protein's Impact on Glucose and Insulin
content: Dr. Richard Bernstein has a clinical practice in Westchester, New York treating specializing in diabetes. He himself has type 1 diabetes. Dr. Bernstein’s book transformed Jake’s thinking about treating diabetes: Dr. Bernstein’s Diabetes Solution: The Complete Guide to Achieving Normal Blood Sugars. The Law of Small Numbers: If you consume more carbs, you need more insulin and therefore there’s a greater opportunity to make a mistake. If you consume fewer carbs, you will consume less insulin and you’ll have fewer mistakes. The book helps both those with type 1 and type 2 diabetes. He figured out that if you avoided carbohydrates and if you give medium and long acting insulin to cover protein and fat and basal metabolic requirements, that you could get blood glucoses very, very close to normal. He typically prescribes a low carb, high protein diet ⇒ It’s not low carb, high fat, it’s not ketogenic. In my patients with type one diabetes who consume protein and don’t cover it with insulin, they can get these massive glucose excursions. And the essence of the Bernstein method is to try cover protein with insulin. And he uses regular insulin (i.e. human insulin), not fast-acting insulin (i.e. Novolog). And the idea is that regular insulin, which is human insulin, has a peak of onset within approximately an hour or two, and it lasts for six to eight hours. So the regular insulin very roughly corresponds with the kinetics of what protein will do to your glucose. Unfortunately the insulin pump companies and even the insulin companies have advocated an approach that says, ‘Look, people who live with type one diabetes have tough lives. We need to support them, and they should be allowed to eat what they want. And they should just cover for it.’ . . .And the problem is you end up with these crazy oscillations. And the oscillations are associated again with a tremendous burden of illness and this cognitive load and this fear and this anxiety.

title: Controlling T1D
content: Their average A1C is 5.7 (“normal as normal gets” says Peter). They also have fewer hypoglycemic events than most T1D patients with a A1C of 7. CGM by Dexcom has been tremendously helpful. He encourages his patients to join the facebook group, TypeOneGrit. And he has fully implemented the Bernstein method with his patients. He also now sees way less patients so that he can spend much more time with each person.

title: Tools for controlling T1D
content: First and foremost, a continuous glucose monitor (CGM) by Dexcom is essential (current model is the G6). Next, it’s important to be informed: Bernstein’s book: Dr. Bernstein’s Diabetes Solution: The Complete Guide to Achieving Normal Blood Sugars. Book by Adam Brown: Bright Spots & Landmines: The Diabetes Guide I Wish Someone Had Handed Me. Facebook group: TypeOneGrit. Various podcasts. Youtube videos: Low Carb Down Under created by Dr. Rod Taylor. Must watch video of lecture by Dr. Troy Stapleton.

title: Is the ketogenic diet appropriate for those with T1D?
content: People with T1D that are trying to get into nutritional ketosis have a few unique problems: 1 Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The normal person has an insulin response that suppresses ketones once it reaches the 6 or 7 millimolar level, where someone with T1D does not have the insulin to do this. So they could reach dangerous levels of ketones resulting in DKA. In other words, prolonged fasting in a person who lives with type one diabetes. 2 Euglycemic DKA. This is a new phenomena. This is seen in T1D patients that are using sodium glucose co-transporter inhibitors (SGLT2 inhibitors). Mostly seeing this is people with T1D, not so much T2D. WARNING: These are not safe (yet) for type 1 diabetics, however, Jake is involved in clinical trials looking to add safety and monitoring mechanisms. 3 Nutritional ketosis and hypoglycemic awareness. People who are in hardcore ketosis who have circulating beta-hydroxybutyrate may become completely immune to low blood glucoses. In other words, there can be cases where someone has dangerously low blood glucose (say 25) and yet they feel fine due to the presence of ketones. The problem, however, is that they may go from feeling fine to fatally low blood glucose without warning.

title: Lessons for non-diabetic population
content: Hyperinsulinemia leads to cardiovascular disease. Lessons from observing treatment options for type 2 diabetics. 2 types of treatments. Metformin, which lowers blood glucose.

title: Insulin and Macrovascular Disease
content: Both of these groups have the same amount of microvascular outcomes (retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy) But the higher insulin treatment groups get more macrovascular diseases (coronary disease, cerebrovascular disease, and peripheral vascular disease) This suggests that insulin is playing a bigger role on the macrovascular disease, and the glucose is playing the role in the microvascular disease

title: SGLT-2 Inhibitors and Cardiovascular Diseases
content: They are the first drugs to have really shown a profound impact on cardiovascular diseases, says Jake Empagliflozin, for example, which directs glucose to the urine and therefore reduces circulating insulin, reduces cardiovascular diseases by 40% Jake cites the work of Cynthia Kenyon

title: Reducing Circulating Insulin
content: Jake believes there’s something to learn from people like Peter’s patient who has type 1 diabetes: Low BMI Very active Low doses of insulin “And I just wonder whether carrying out these tricks to try to reduce your circulating insulin could be incredibly beneficial.”

title: Peter's Dream Measurements
content: First, metabolic signature for autophagy Second, a way to measure the amount of insulin made by your pancreases over the previous 24 hours (a.k.a. Insulin AUC)
